item.title: Was housing the problem in Australia's 'surprising' economic check up?
item.description: Some economists blamed housing for raising inflation but energy prices soared more than 37 per cent in the twelve months to October 2025.

item.title: Controversy over Melbourne event appearing to celebrate Israeli pager operation
item.description: Lebanese and Jewish groups have condemned a planned event in Melbourne that appears to celebrate last year's Israeli pager operation in Lebanon, which killed dozens and injured thousands more. The event run by the group called Lions of Zion has been labelled 'disgraceful' - but organisers say they are celebrating what they describe as one of the most ingenious military operations in history.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 27 November 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: All about Australia's biggest environmental reforms this century
item.description: After five years of review, the government has struck a deal with the Greens to pass the largest reforms to Australia’s environmental laws in 26 years, which includes new environmental standards, protections for native forests, and the effective end of fast-tracked approvals for coal and gas projects. Despite these wins, the deal faces criticism from environmental experts.

item.title: Ukraine peace plan or Putin power play? Climate COP-out and Trump’s new bromance…
item.description: Alarm bells in Kyiv and Europe as the US is accused of presenting Putin’s peace plan for Ukraine. The ‘make or break’ COP30 climate conference ends in failure – have the petro-states won? Plus, the unlikely bromance blossoming in the Oval Office.

item.title: Australia is facing a hot summer — but the forecast comes with caveats
item.description: With little rainfall, there's an increased fire risk for parts of Australia, and authorities are urging caution.

item.title: Australia falling well short of 2035 climate target, as Bowen concedes more work needed
item.description: The federal government has already acknowledged tougher policies would be needed to meet the 2035 goal.

item.title: APRA tightens lending rules, and investors continue to question rate outlook
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Nathan Zaia from Morningstar about APRA's tightening of lending rules for high risk borrowers to find out if it will make a difference; plus, the day on the sharemarket with Hugh Lam from Betashares.

item.title: The most common holiday-season scams targeting Australians — and how to spot them
item.description: Some Australians are reporting losses of up to $5,000 due to scams during the holiday shopping season.

item.title: 'Lions of Zion' group event celebrating Israel's pager attacks condemned
item.description: Victoria Police has said it will continue to monitor the event billed as "fun for all ages".

item.title: Israeli forces kill Palestinian men who appeared to be surrendering in West Bank raid
item.description: Footage appeared to show Israeli security forces shoot and kill two unarmed Palestinian men who were attempting to surrender during a raid in Jenin in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 28 November 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Why these near-identical Chinese restaurants have caused mass confusion
item.description: Its plastic grapes and braised eggplant are an iconic Sydney staple. But Chinese Noodle House's closure has sparked grief ... and confusion.

item.title: Increased bushfire risk in parts of Australia this summer, fire authorities warn
item.description: The latest bushfire outlook forecasts an increased fire risk across parts of Australia this summer. Despite recent rainfall in the country's southeast, authorities say it won't take long for a blaze to take hold.

item.title: Trump announces migration freeze for ‘third world countries’ after national guard shooting
item.description: The US president said the plan would include cases approved under former president Joe Biden's administration.

item.title: Exclusive: El Jannah CEO speaks with SBS as company goes global & ASX rises
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with El Jannah CEO Brett Houldin as the charcoal chicken company secures international funding valuing it at hundreds of millions of dollars, allowing it to quadruple its national footprint and explore options in the Middle-East; plus the week on the sharemarket with Tony Sycamore from IG Markets Securities Limited.

item.title: The billion dollar deportation deal Australia doesn't want to talk about ft. David Shoebridge
item.description: Australia is expected to spend billions of dollars to deport non-citizens to the small Pacific nation of Nauru. Meanwhile, Pauline Hanson as repeated a years-old stunt, environment laws have passed, and Barnaby Joyce has cosied up with One Nation. Greens Senator David Shoebridge talks about the Nauru deal, after a translation of an interview with the nation's president was controversially put on the record in the Senate.

item.title: 'Time to step forward': Australia could be making billions with this untapped export
item.description: Japan and South Korea are both soft power success stories. Here's how Australia could follow suit.

item.title: See the list: The Aussie suburbs where home prices more than doubled in five years
item.description: Domain's latest house price report reveals an uptick in desirability for regional suburbs, away from the CBD.

item.title: How Olympia’s 'maggot farms' are helping to tackle a $36 billion problem
item.description: In Australia, around 7.6 million tonnes of food is wasted every year. One female-founder has developed a solution in a box.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Australian youth identify cost of living as top concern in survey
item.description: Cost of living was the number one challenge identified by Australian youth surveyed by Mission Australia.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Australian youth identify cost of living as top concern in survey
item.description: Cost of living was the number one challenge identified by Australian youth surveyed by Mission Australia.

item.title: Here's what we know about the Airbus A320 recall
item.description: The global recall for Airbus A320s is impacting Australian travellers, with Jetstar reporting cancellations of some of its flights.

item.title: Here's what we know about the Airbus A320 recall
item.description: The global recall for Airbus A320s is impacting Australian travellers, with Jetstar reporting cancellations of some of its flights.

item.title: Olympia farms millions of maggots in Aussie warehouses — for this $36bn reason
item.description: Australia is wasting 7.6 million tonnes of food a year.

item.title: How El Jannah grew from a family charcoal chicken restaurant to a global contender
item.description: In an exclusive interview, El Jannah CEO Brett Houldin tells SBS News of the Lebanese chicken chain's global ambitions after a major US buyout.

item.title: Australia blitzed transmission of HIV, but a neighbour's crisis threatens the entire region
item.description: Australia has committed $48m to support Fiji's fast-growing HIV crisis, targeting testing, treatment and community-led prevention.

item.title: Prime Minister 'delighted' as he celebrates wedding to fiancée Jodie Haydon
item.description: The Prime Minister and his fiancée Jodie Hayden have just married, at a ceremony in the nation’s capital. The country's been kept guessing as to exactly when the wedding would take place for months.

item.title: From DMs to 'I do': The Rabbitohs romance that led to Australia's 'royal wedding'
item.description: A six-year romance between Anthony Albanese and Jodie Haydon began with social media messages and a shared love of footy.

item.title: The surprising technology that could be key to saving the Great Barrier Reef
item.description: First Nations rangers from the world's biggest reef are learning coral spawning techniques in one of the largest restoration trials to date.

item.title: Trump declares Venezuela airspace 'closed in its entirety' as tensions surge
item.description: Venezuela's government condemned Trump's comments, describing them as a "colonialist threat" against the country's sovereignty.

item.title: Trump declares Venezuela airspace 'closed in its entirety' as tensions surge
item.description: Venezuela's government condemned Trump's comments, describing them as a "colonialist threat" against the country's sovereignty.

item.title: 'At risk of losing everything': The frontline rangers protecting the Great Barrier Reef
item.description: Indigenous rangers from the Great Barrier Reef are learning coral spawning techniques in one of the largest reef restoration trials to date. The pilot program involves rangers working in the reefs off Queensland's Keppel Islands, which were hit hard by last year's mass coral bleaching event.

item.title: Russian missiles and 'anarchisation': How could Venezuela respond to a US attack?
item.description: The Venezuelan foreign ministry called the latest remarks from Donald Trump a "new extravagant, illegal, and unjustified aggression against the people of Venezuela".

item.title: A new values test for temporary visa holders 'won't hurt', David Littleproud says
item.description: The Coalition is set to unveil its immigration policy, expected to include cuts to migration levels, by the year's end.

item.title: Expert view: Will Australia have another Christmas COVID wave this year?
item.description: Since the start of the pandemic, Australia has experienced an increase in COVID-19 cases during the summer and winter months.

item.title: Expert view: Will Australia have another Christmas COVID wave this year?
item.description: Since the start of the pandemic, Australia has experienced an increase in COVID-19 cases during the summer and winter months.

item.title: Nationwide passport system outage leaves travellers stuck at airports
item.description: Passengers reportedly had to be processed manually through immigration services.

item.title: 'I remember being so scared': Chrissy's traumatic three-year battle to have her ex convicted
item.description: Chrissy says she faced traumatic experiences navigating the justice system.

item.title: 'He's been buried twice': Why John had to open his brother's grave after 49 years
item.description: Recent findings of a coronial inquest confirmed that 177 human specimens were handed to the University of Tasmania without consent.

item.title: Netanyahu seeks 'extraordinary' presidential pardon amid ongoing corruption trial
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has argued that his legal proceedings impede his ability to govern and a pardon would benefit Israel.

item.title: Soaring home prices erase benefits of recent interest rate cuts
item.description: Data from Cotality shows rapid home price growth across Australia has erased affordability gains from recent rate cuts.

item.title: 'Can't afford to ask nicely anymore': Why Myles locked himself to port equipment
item.description: NSW Police have charged more than 150 people in relation to the protests.

item.title: Protests follow request for pardon by Netanyahu
item.description: Israel is facing a political shock wave after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu formally asked President Isaac Herzog for a pardon in his ongoing corruption trial. The unprecedented move has triggered fierce protests, legal warnings and a deeply polarised public debate over whether clemency would unify the nation or erode the rule of law.

item.title: Global arms giants hit record $1 trillion in revenue, fuelled by Ukraine and Gaza wars
item.description: An increase in national defence spending also contributed to a surge in sales for the world's largest arms-makers.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 1 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Australia monitoring Chinese 'task group' in the Philippine Sea
item.description: The news came as Acting Prime Minister Richard Marles announced a huge shake-up of Australia's defence department.

item.title: 'Moving in the wrong direction': The debt divide leaving some Australians even worse off
item.description: Housing remains the top financial concern for Australians amid unrelenting cost of living issues, though many are continuing to save.

item.title: ASX outage hits company announcements & property price growth eases
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Weston from Pepperstone about the day's market action including another outage at the ASX. Plus Eliza Owen from Cotality Australia takes a look at the latest property price data and future moves.

item.title: 'Historic': WHO releases first guidance on drugs like Ozempic for treating obesity
item.description: The World Health Organization has published its first set of recommendations regarding medications for weight loss.

item.title: Government announces long-awaited national plan for artificial intelligence
item.description: The plan is aimed at "making sure technology serves Australians, not the other way around", Industry Minister Tim Ayres said.

item.title: Rate cuts? What rate cuts - Home prices have eaten them alive
item.description: New data reveals that surging home prices have wiped away the benefits of three interest rate cuts to new buyers. Rent prices are also rising in every capital city, prompting more and more Australians to form larger households or move back to their family home. The rising prices have left economists predicting a possible rate hike in 2026.

item.title: 'Cast off' divisions: Pope Leo's message as tens of thousands gather for Beirut mass
item.description: Pope Leo has described his trip to Lebanon, racked by years of conflict, political paralysis and economic misery, as a mission of peace.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 2 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Rhetoric and 'gunboat' diplomacy: Is Trump pushing the US toward war with Venezuela?
item.description: United States President Donald Trump has threatened a ground invasion of Venezuela to disrupt what he claims is a vast drug-trafficking network. The US military has already deployed thousands of troops and dozens of warships to the Caribbean as a US air campaign that has killed at least 83 people continues. But how likely is an all-out war with their South American neighbour, really?

item.title: 'I wish I was a dog in Australia': Muhammad's story as UN probes immigration detention
item.description: Australia's immigration detention regime is under United Nations scrutiny this week. The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention is examining how the country deprives people of their liberty — from prisons to offshore detention facilities. And for people like Muhammad, who spent six years in detention, this review is one that's long overdue.

item.title: Tomi bought her spa weeks ago. She’s fighting to stay open after Groupon failed to pay up
item.description: A small business owner has taken on Groupon over missing payments.

item.title: Thousands of Samsung phones may still be unable to call triple-zero, estimates hears
item.description: The findings were presented by the Australian Communications and Media Authority in Senate estimates.

item.title: Who is Nicolas Maduro, the ex-bus driver and world leader accused of narco-terrorism?
item.description: There have been mounting tensions between Venezuela and the United States over alleged narco-terrorism.

item.title: ASX edges higher ahead of GDP data | Silver breaks new record
item.description: The Australian share market has closed higher ahead of tomorrow’s key GDP data, where a strong economic growth figure could further complicate the Reserve Bank’s interest rate decision next week. Plus, silver’s rally continues with the precious metal breaking above US$58 an ounce overnight. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with MPC Markets CEO Mark Gardner.

item.title: One year since Assad was toppled, these Australians are still waiting for answers
item.description: The US wants countries to repatriate its detained citizens from Syria. But Australia's government insists it’s "not" doing that.

item.title: Sara's partner, brother and father are Australian citizens. But she can never be one
item.description: A group of around 900 asylum seekers who came to Australia by boat nearly 13 years ago remain stuck in visa limbo, fighting for permanency.

item.title: eSafety commissioner hits back at US politician's 'zealot for global takedowns' claim
item.description: eSafety commissioner Julie Inman Grant said she would be sending a letter "explaining a few things" to US politician Jim Jordan.

item.title: Putin accuses Europeans of sabotaging Ukraine peace efforts | Morning Bulletin 3 December 2025
item.description: Vladimir Putin accuses Europeans of sabotaging Ukraine peace efforts with their demands, Another One Nation member faces accusations of fuelling Islamophobia, Sam Kerr helps the Matildas win against New Zealand in Adelaide.

item.title: What 16,000 Australians reveal about the hidden realities of working from home
item.description: Does working from home really boost wellbeing — and does one gender benefit more? Here's what new research suggests.

item.title: US under fire for drug-trafficking strikes at sea
item.description: The United States faces mounting accusations of extrajudicial killings after launching lethal airstrikes on suspected drug-trafficking vessels in the waters of the Caribbean and East Pacific Ocean. A follow-up strike on survivors from a disabled boat on September the 2nd has sparked particular outrage, with legal experts and the U-N saying the attacks violate international law, and the Pentagon’s own rules against targeting the shipwrecked.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'We're looking at it very seriously': Trump eyes Australia's superannuation scheme
item.description: Trump says his administration is considering an Australian-style superannuation system, but it's not clear how the policy would be adopted.

item.title: Nearly 44,000 Australians are owed Centrelink refunds. Some died without knowing
item.description: Services Australia told SBS News they've refunded $2.9 million to just 338 of the 44,000 people potentially owed money.

item.title: The worries of young Australians in 2025
item.description: Teenagers are more concerned than ever about the cost of living, according the annual Mission Australia Youth Survey of more than 17,000 young people. Financial worries have jumped significantly in survey results in recent years, with climate change falling as an issue of concern, and mental health still having a large impact.

item.title: Australian economy grows at fastest pace in two years
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Stephen Halmarick from Economists Unchained and Alice Shen from VanEck to find out what today's official GDP data really says about the economy, implications for interest rates, and how the sharemarket reacted.

item.title: What Australians now expect from landlords
item.description: As new minimum standards start to gain traction, so too are expectations that landlords — at least in part — cover the cost of meeting them.

item.title: 350 Australians a day: What happens to those on the edge of a housing crisis
item.description: More Australians at risk of homelessness are being turned away as frontline services buckle under worsening housing and safety pressures.

item.title: Hamas hands over remains believed to be one of Gaza's last hostages
item.description: Israel has received a body that Hamas says is one of the last two deceased hostages remaining in Gaza, pending forensic identification.

item.title: How much super will you need? The new figure to retire comfortably
item.description: Bucket list trips? Streaming subscriptions? Here's how much you'll need to retire comfortably, according to an industry peak body.

item.title: Australia's 'mateship' package for Ukraine praised but questions remain on sanctions
item.description: The latest $95 million package includes funds for military procurement and targeted sanctions on an additional 45 Russian "shadow fleet" vessels

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 4 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Should adults opt in to switch off their social media algorithm, as kids get banned?
item.description: Ahead of the under-16s social media ban, activists have urged the government to introduce an opt-in feature for social media algorithms.

item.title: Border Force detains six Chinese men who arrived in remote WA community by boat
item.description: Western Australia police said an off-duty officer located two men 12km north of Kalumburu on Monday.

item.title: How helpful is carbon capture in mitigating global warming?
item.description: A new European Union initiative to store carbon dioxide beneath the North Sea is set to launch its operations next year. But environmental activists are concerned carbon capture technologies dissuade industries from acting to reduce fossil fuel emissions.

item.title: SE Asia flood crisis, Putin’s Moscow musings & Austria’s rebel nuns return
item.description: Devastating floods and landslides wreak havoc across much of south-east Asia. No compromise reached after the Russian President and the US try to iron out a revamped peace proposal for Ukraine. Plus, the asylum seekers living in limbo – why they’re pleading with the Australian government to grant them leniency - and the rebel nuns refusing to give up their social media accounts.

item.title: RBA could hike rates sooner than expected | How much super do you need?
item.description: A boost to the copper price and weaker US jobs data improving rate cut sentiment has helped lift the Australian share market, despite stronger than expected household spending data dampening hopes of future interest rate cuts locally. In fact, markets are increasingly pricing-in rate hikes in 2026. For more on this, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Morningstar chief investment officer Matt Wacher. Plus, ASFA CEO Mary Delahunty on the superannuation peak body’s latest Retirement Standard.

item.title: 'I wish I was a dog in Australia': Ex-immigration detainee speaks out as scheme investigated
item.description: The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention is examining how the country deprives people of their liberty, from prisons to offshore detention facilities.

item.title: The latest travel advice for Southeast Asia amid deadly storms, floods affecting millions
item.description: Travel warnings remain in place for parts of Asia where locals say they have "lost it all" as they take stock of the damage.

item.title: Israel to perform at Eurovision 2026 as Spain, Netherlands, Ireland and Slovenia withdraw
item.description: Israel's participation has divided opinion in the contest, which has a history of entanglement in political rivalries and international issues.

item.title: What we know about the Trump-brokered DR Congo–Rwanda peace deal
item.description: Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo have signed a US-brokered peace accord aimed at ending the long-running conflict in eastern DRC.

item.title: 'Force of arms': Putin makes strong Donbas threat, adding pressure on peace deal
item.description: Putin's territorial demand is something that Ukraine has never given any indication it would accept.

item.title: Australia’s social media ban to follow teens overseas — and hit visa holders
item.description: As Meta starts enforcing the social media ban, uncertainty grows over how the rules may affect young visitors and international students.

item.title: 'Give us a chance': More than 900 asylum seekers still in visa limbo in Australia
item.description: A group of around 900 asylum seekers who came to Australia by boat nearly 13 years ago remain stuck in visa limbo, fighting for permanency. Despite living and working in Australia for nearly a decade, they have no pathway to permanent residency thanks to a hardline 2013 immigration policy on boat arrivals. They're pleading with the Australian government to grant them leniency, as a last hope. And a warning - this story contains descriptions of self harm that some may find distressing.

item.title: Can Eurovision survive? Four countries withdraw from contest over Israel's eligibility
item.description: Europe’s largest cultural event is once again confronting the tension between entertainment and geopolitics. After the European Broadcasting Union formally confirmed Israel’s eligibility for the 2026 Eurovision Song Contest, four countries - Spain, the Netherlands, Ireland and Slovenia - immediately withdrew. Their walkout has triggered one of the most serious disputes in the contest’s modern history, raising questions about neutrality, artistic expression and how far Eurovision can distance itself from real-world conflicts.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 5 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Revealed: The travel hotspots Australians are heading to this summer
item.description: Almost three-quarters of Australians will be heading on holiday this summer — but many are choosing to stay closer to home.

item.title: 'Worst job in politics': Vincent Tarzia steps down as South Australia's Opposition leader
item.description: Tarzia is the third state Liberal to lose the leadership in as many weeks.

item.title: OpenAI invests in Australia & markets prepare for US and local interest rates decision
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Harry Morrow from Loftus Peak to find out more about OpenAI's new Australian intitiative including plans for a $7bn hyper data centre with NextDC; plus the day on the sharemarket with Omkar Joshi at Opal Capital Management.

item.title: US says there are opportunities to put AUKUS on 'strongest footing' after five-month review
item.description: Defence Minister Richard Marles said on Thursday that Australia is "working through" the review, which has has not been made public.

item.title: Uluru's Ayers Rock Resort sold to US-owned tourism company
item.description: Land and buildings at the resort will be transferred to Traditional Owners, the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara.

item.title: First time since 1974: Australia's FIFA World Cup 2026 opponents revealed
item.description: The most logistically complex World Cup in history will be held across the United States, Mexico and Canada from 11 June to 19 July.

item.title: First time since 1974: Australia's FIFA World Cup 2026 opponents revealed
item.description: The most logistically complex World Cup in history will be held across the United States, Mexico and Canada from 11 June to 19 July.

item.title: First time since 1974: Australia's FIFA World Cup 2026 opponents revealed
item.description: The most logistically complex World Cup in history will be held across the United States, Mexico and Canada from 11 June to 19 July.

item.title: Nightmares and PTSD: The reality of surviving a shark attack
item.description: Being bitten by a shark or other predator can leave lifelong scars. One survivor started a club for those who've lived to tell the tale.

item.title: For Australian retailers, Christmas cheer turns to fear as theft soars
item.description: As the festive shopping rush begins, vendors are bracing for a surge in shoplifting. Australia-wide, theft has hit a 21-year high. Experts say it’s part of a broader trend.

item.title: For Australian retailers, Christmas cheer turns to fear as theft soars
item.description: As the festive shopping rush begins, vendors are bracing for a surge in shoplifting. Australia-wide, theft has hit a 21-year high. Experts say it’s part of a broader trend.

item.title: What is the FIFA peace prize, and why was Trump selected as the inaugural recipient?
item.description: Last month, FIFA announced that a new annual award called the FIFA peace prize would be presented at the draw.

item.title: 'Make memories’: the tragic reality of childhood DIPG and the new research giving families hope
item.description: An Australian cancer research centre has been awarded a 2.5 million dollar grant to further their research into one of the country 's deadliest brain cancers. Researchers at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute in Melbourne hope to fast-track diagnosis and treatment options.

item.title: More than a dozen NSW homes lost as firefighters battle blazes amid extreme heat
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns said it was a "challenging day for NSW firefighters".

item.title: 'Deeply concerned': Australia sanctions top Taliban leaders
item.description: The federal government has similar sanctions in place for other countries, including Iran, Russia and North Korea.

item.title: The 'everyday' behaviour that has shop owners in Australia worried — and it's on the rise
item.description: As Christmas nears, increasing retail theft is costing profits and putting staff at risk. What's behind it?

item.title: Trump administration suggests US 'cultivate resistance' within Europe to 'current trajectory'
item.description: US President Donald Trump's new national security strategy marks a radical departure from previous US policy.

item.title: How a 'weaker' La Niña could impact Australia differently this summer
item.description: La Niña is here, but not the one you're picturing. This year's event is shaping up to be "weak" — and the forecast points to a hotter, drier summer instead.

item.title: Australia up against World Cup co-hosts as the 2026 draw is made
item.description: The draw has been made for the 2026 FIFA World Cup - and Australia are up against the co-hosts.

item.title: The fake Indian wedding tying the knot between trend and tradition
item.description: The global, growing and glamorous trend of South Asian weddings — sans bride and groom — has landed on Australian soil.

item.title: Ethel took a job in Australia to support her family. She says she was 'left with nothing'
item.description: There are estimated to be more than 7,000 Pacific Island workers in Australia's agriculture and meat sectors at risk of exploitation.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Do oysters have ears? Dr Dominic McAfee shares a unique method for oyster regeneration
item.description: That's the sound of snapping shrimp - music to oyster ears. Dr Dominic McAfee has been playing this sound underwater to help regenerate natural oyster reefs. He's been doing this work for years, but recently, there's been an upswell in interest, as the South Australian government tries to increase resilience against a harmful algal bloom. The ongoing environmental crisis has killed hundreds of species and resulted in tens, possibly hundreds, of thousands of marine deaths. Dr McAfee says South Australia used to be home to huge oyster reefs, which would have curbed the intensity of the algal bloom because they naturally filter the water. He’s speaking here with SBS's Tee Mitchell, who started by asking about the role and extent of oyster reefs before colonisation.

item.title: Christmas lights return to Bethlehem for first time since Gaza war
item.description: A giant Christmas tree adorned with red and gold baubles stands in the West Bank city of Bethlehem for the first time since 2022.

item.title: 'A very painful day': India nightclub fire in Goa leaves 25 people dead
item.description: A fire in a nightclub in India's tourist hot spot of Goa has killed 25 people.

item.title: Fears for thousands of Afghans in Australia amid 'secrecy' over potential shutdown
item.description: Senator Fatima Payman said the Afghan embassy's closure would be 'the second fall of Afghanistan'. Insiders say it's barely been operating.

item.title: Communications Minister defends a taxpayer-funded trip | Midday Bulletin 7 December 2025
item.description: Communications Minister Anika Wells defends a taxpayer-funded trip to New York, An investigation underway after 12 homes destroyed in fires on the New South Wales Central Coast, Oscar Piastri aiming to win the Formula One world championship.

item.title: 'At a loss': NSW bushfire victims in shock as disaster payments unlocked
item.description: Disaster payments are now available for communities hit by bushfires across NSW, with authorities warning of ongoing risks and urging vigilance this summer.

item.title: Migrant workers like Ethel feel abandoned by this scrutinised government scheme
item.description: The Pacific Australia Labour Mobility scheme, often known as the PALM scheme, allows eligible Australian businesses to hire workers from the Pacific for either short-term or long-term roles. But the scheme has been under scrutiny following media reports of worker exploitation and harsh working conditions, and advocates and unions have been urging the government to launch a reform.

item.title: 'That's not neutrality': Protesters call on SBS to boycott Eurovision
item.description: Protesters have demanded SBS boycott the Eurovision Song Contest over Israel’s participation, but the public broadcaster said such a move would undermine its editorial independence.

item.title: 'It's nasty': Could this virus spark the world's next pandemic?
item.description: Epidemiologists are keeping a close eye on the H5 bird flu strains that are present in parts of the world.

item.title: Netanyahu says phase two of Gaza peace plan nears but key disputes remain
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated that progress toward the second phase of a US-backed plan to end the Gaza war is close.

item.title: Kremlin praises Trump's new security strategy as closely aligned with Russia's vision
item.description: The Kremlin offered unusually strong praise for US President Donald Trump’s new national security strategy, saying it aligns closely with Russia’s own strategic outlook.

item.title: Man killed battling NSW blaze was 'experienced firefighter' and divisional leader
item.description: The 59-year-old had worked for the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service since 1996, the NSW environment minister said.

item.title: Firefighter killed in New South Wales | Midday News Bulletin 8 December 2025
item.description: A firefighter dies while fighting a fire in New South Wales; aid reaches hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in Gaza and Jessica Stenson breaks the Australian marathon record.

item.title: Littleproud takes aim at Joyce after One Nation defection as Hanson outlines plan
item.description: After quitting the Nationals, Barnaby Joyce has joined One Nation as leader Pauline Hanson outlines her 2028 election plan for the MP.

item.title: Netanyahu says Israel nearing phase two of Gaza Ceasefire Plan
item.description: Israel is close to moving into the second phase of the Gaza ceasefire agreement, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cautioning that the next steps will be “more difficult” as tensions continue over Hamas’s disarmament, Gaza’s future governance, and the stalled two-state solution. Speaking in Jerusalem with German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, Mr Netanyahu received strong backing for Israel’s security while also confronting growing international scrutiny over alleged human rights breaches during the Gaza war.

item.title: Thailand launches airstrikes along disputed border with Cambodia
item.description: Both sides are trading blame for the latest eruption in fighting along their border.

item.title: Communities on high alert along NSW coast as firefighter dies battling blaze
item.description: Summer heat and high winds have fuelled a dangerous weekend of bush and grass fires across New South Wales, leaving more than 20 homes destroyed and claiming the life of a firefighter. The man died after being struck by a falling tree late Sunday while battling a blaze near Bulahdelah, with Premier Chris Minns saying the loss is devastating. Conditions eased by Monday, but authorities say nine fires remain uncontained across the state.

item.title: Energy bill rebates to be axed in cost of living relief 'shift'
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers said tax cuts will instead help Australians to pay electricity bills and meet other cost of living pressures.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 8 December 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Got a lot on your plate? Food poisoning can sleigh the Christmas spirit, experts warn
item.description: There can be a lot on our plates at this time of year - and our meals can come with a side of sickness. The Australian Food Safety Information Council has released its top tips for how to enjoy the season safely - aiming to reduce more than four and a half million* [[4.67M]] cases of food poisoning each year.

item.title: Minister defends travel expenses as Coalition demands independent review
item.description: Communications Minister Annika Wells is under intense public scrutiny over her travel expenses, from last-minute flights to the UN to attend an event on social media reform. It has sparked revelations over other expenses she has made, including thousands on a family entitlement to visit a ski resort and lavish meals out in Paris during the Olympics. While the Minister insists all costs adhered to official rules, critics argue her expenditure is exorbitant and fails the "pub test," prompting calls for a full independent review.

item.title: Joyce to join One Nation| Evening News Bulletin 8 December 2025
item.description: Barnaby Joyce to join One Nation; energy rebates to end and in the NRL, the West Tigers are now without a CEO.

item.title: Markets brace for global interest rate decisions
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Luke McMillan from Ophir Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action including how the market is positioning itself ahead of key interest rates decisions out of the US and Australia.

item.title: Former nurse Rajwinder Singh found guilty of murdering Toyah Cordingley in 2018
item.description: A $1 million reward was offered in late 2022 for information leading to the location and arrest of Rajwinder Singh.

item.title: 'Really nasty': The Christmas mistake Australians make — and what to do instead
item.description: And it's not the only handy tip to know while planning your Christmas spread.

item.title: Australia's teen social media ban: Here are all the key details
item.description: Platforms face up to $49.5 million in fines if they do not take "reasonable steps" to prevent under-16s from holding an account.

item.title: 'Six-foot-high pile': The unwanted fast fashion overwhelming op shops
item.description: Australians feel good donating clothes, but donation bins are being flooded with fast fashion and soiled items — and it’s costing op shops.

item.title: Tsunami warning lifted after magnitude-7.5 earthquake strikes Japan
item.description: The tremor struck off Japan's north-eastern coast about 11.15pm local time, prompting warnings — later lifted — of waves up to three metres high.

item.title: Tsunami warning lifted after magnitude-7.5 earthquake strikes Japan
item.description: The tremor struck off Japan's north-eastern coast about 11.15pm local time, prompting warnings — later lifted — of waves up to three metres high.

item.title: European leaders back Zelenskyy at ‘crucial time’ for Ukraine
item.description: European leaders have met Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in London amid growing US pressure for a proposed peace deal with Russia.

item.title: Australia and US hold high-level security talks | Morning News Bulletin 9 December 2025
item.description: Australia and the US hold high-level security talks as the alliance focuses on Indo-Pacific tensions; A magnitude 7.6 earthquake strikes Japan; Shane Richardson calls on NRL boss to look after Tigers fans.

item.title: 'Full steam ahead': US commits to AUKUS pact after defence talks in Washington
item.description: The talks touched on AUKUS, critical minerals and security in the Indo-Pacific amid China's increasing assertiveness.

item.title: How the Thailand-Cambodia conflict went from Trump-backed ceasefire to airstrikes
item.description: Border clashes between the two countries have erupted, months after they signed a US-brokered ceasefire. But why has the fighting reignited?

item.title: TPG reveals second possible fatality linked to triple-zero failure
item.description: A second death may be linked to a triple-zero failure from some devices on the TPG Telecom network, a Senate inquiry has heard.

item.title: One year after Al-Assad's fall: Syria's journey towards a new future
item.description: Syria's President is calling for Syrians to help the country become an advanced nation, as it celebrates one year since the fall of of former President Bashar al-Assad. Thousands of Syrians have taken to the streets to celebrate, waving the country’s new green flag , which for years was used by opposition forces during an uprising that became a civil war.

item.title: First Karen lost her mum. Then the fires came and burned all the memories
item.description: Fires are burning across Tasmania and NSW, with dozens of homes destroyed and critical infrastructure damaged.

item.title: Victoria to issue apology to state's Indigenous community | Midday News Bulletin 9 December 2025
item.description: Victoria to issue an official apology to the state's First Nations communities; A date set for Israel's Prime Minister to meet with the US President; Alex De Minaur collects his fourth John Newcombe medal.

item.title: 'We say sorry': Victorian govt delivers historic apology to state's Indigenous people
item.description: The apology comes after Victoria passed an Australian-first statewide treaty in October.

item.title: One of the best meteor showers peaks this weekend. Here's how to watch it from Australia
item.description: Australia will enter a peak Geminids window this weekend as moonless skies promise one of the strongest meteor displays of the year.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: European leaders meet Ukrainian President as US-led ceasefire negotiations gather pace
item.description: European leaders have met the Ukrainian President in London, in a show of support as United States-led ceasefire negotiations gather pace. The allies sought to strengthen Ukraine's position, amid concerns the emerging US proposal could pressure the nation into accepting terms favourable to Russia. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says soon he will present a revised 20-point peace proposal to the United States, though major disagreements around territory remain unresolved.

item.title: Why are Australians having to wait for access to the latest medical technology?
item.description: A new national report has found that Australians are facing an average five-year wait for life-saving medical technologies. The report says that while medical technology is advancing rapidly overseas, Australia's system is still slow to approve and fund the new technologies.

item.title: Former nurse Rajwinder Singh handed life sentence for murder of Toyah Cordingley
item.description: Singh was found guilty on Monday after a jury in Cairns' Supreme Court deliberated for about seven hours.

item.title: Reserve Bank governor's warning about interest rates next year
item.description: Major banks and economists broadly predicted the cash rate would remain at 3.6 per cent.

item.title: 'Frightening': UN human rights team blocked from NT prisons and youth detention centres
item.description: A United Nations working group has been barred from accessing youth prisons, detention centres, and watch houses in the NT.

item.title: Reserve Bank leaves rates unchanged ahead of Christmas | Evening News Bulletin 9 December 2025
item.description: Victoria's historic apology to First Nations people another step in the treaty process; The Reserve Bank issues its final rates decision for the year; Saudi fans await confirmation Mo Salah will join Al-Hilal.

item.title: AUSMIN talks in Washington confirm AUKUS is progressing
item.description: Top security officials from the United States and Australia have met in Washington, confirming that the AUKUS security pact is moving "full steam ahead," despite the Pentagon's five-month review of the deal remaining secret. Both nations emphasised increased defence spending, critical minerals cooperation, and greater burden-sharing from allies to confront growing Indo-Pacific tensions.

item.title: No more interest rate cuts: the RBA's warning
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Paul Bloxham from HSBC and Stuart Roberts from Stocks Down Under about why the RBA decision to leave interest rates on hold at its December board meeting and the increasing chance the next move in rates will be up, not down.

item.title: 'Profound shock': Family honours experienced firefighter killed in the line of duty
item.description: The 59-year-old was helping lead the charge against the Bulahdelah fire when he was killed.

item.title: The global fault lines emerging over Australia's social media ban
item.description: While Australia's world first under-16s social media ban is domestic in scope, its diplomatic implications appear to be far-reaching.

item.title: The simple question at hospital that saved Stuart's life
item.description: A new national report has found that Australians are facing an average five-year wait for life-saving medical technologies.

item.title: Social media ban kicks off today | Morning Bulletin 10 December 2025
item.description: The social media ban kicks in as the Communications Minister refers her expenses for audit, Conflict on the Thai-Cambodia border continues to escalate with several people reported dead, The AFLW draft goes down to the wire.

item.title: Trump renews attacks on 'weak' Europe as he pressures Ukraine to hold wartime elections
item.description: Donald Trump listed countries including Britain, France, Germany, Poland and Sweden that he said were being "destroyed" by migration.

item.title: Why are balloons from Belarus creating an 'emergency situation' in Lithuania?
item.description: Lithuania has declared an emergency after high-altitude balloons disrupted hundreds of flights. What are they?

item.title: At least two properties damaged as firefighters battle Tasmania bushfire
item.description: Local residents have been evacuated, as a fire threatens several communities on the east coast.

item.title: 'It won't be perfect': Albanese hails social media ban as it faces 'teething issues'
item.description: Enforcement challenges emerge as the social media ban takes effect, while the eSafety boss compares it to gun reform and predicts others will follow.

item.title: 'Adjustment issues' on day one of Australia's social media ban | Midday News Bulletin 10 December 2025
item.description: Teething problems emerge on day one of Australia's social media ban; Indigenous children still being removed from families at staggering rates; Tottenham Hotspur emerge victorious in their latest Champions League home game.

item.title: Fighting escalates on Thai-Cambodian border
item.description: Fighting between Cambodia and Thailand has escalated along their contested border on Tuesday, with the Southeast Asian neighbours both saying they will not back down in defending their sovereignty. With each side is blaming the other for starting Monday's renewed clashes, and it's unclear how or if a fragile ceasefire brokered by US President Donald Trump in July can be salvaged.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 December
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Trump renews attacks on Europe and pressures Ukraine to hold wartime elections
item.description: United States President Donald Trump has escalated his criticism of Europe in a controversial new interview, claiming the continent is “decaying” due to weak immigration policies. He also hit out at Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who he sees as an obstacle to peace between Ukraine and Russia, and questioned Ukraine's credentials as a democracy.

item.title: Commissioner promises to enforce new social media age ban | Evening News Bulletin 10 December 2025
item.description: Australia's underage social media ban hailed as an example for the world; A Muslim civil rights group branded a foreign terrorist organisation in the United States; Pat Cummins back in Australia's squad for the Ashes.

item.title: 'Impossible problem': The retirees who may need an extra $300k in super
item.description: Some people will have to save 1.5 times more than others to have a 'dignified retirement', according to a new analysis

item.title: Social media ban sparks creative evasion and digital ID security fears
item.description: The Australian government has implemented the world's first social media ban for all under-16s, citing the protection of developing adolescent brains. But the move faces immediate backlash from teenagers who are sharing evasion tactics.

item.title: Crocodiles v humans: Safety crackdown could backfire, environmentalist says
item.description: Expansions to crocodile removal zones and increased patrols are part of a plan to increase public safety.

item.title: ETFs surge in popularity & markets betting on an RBA rate rise in 2026
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Andrew McAuley from UBS Global Wealth Management Australia about the changing interest rate outlook and what it means for 2026; Cameron Gleeson from Betashares explains the recent pick up in ETF activity; and a look at the day on the sharemarket with Hebe Chen from Vantage Australia.

item.title: Australia’s teen social media ban: How day one unfolded — and the world’s response
item.description: A year after clearing parliament, the teen social media ban finally took effect. But its debut was not without issues.

item.title: My brother lived without an autism diagnosis for four decades. I wish it came sooner
item.description: For most of his life, Helen’s brother John didn’t know he was autistic. He was diagnosed in the 1970s — a time of limited understanding of neurodiversity.

item.title: US could ask Australian tourists to submit five years of social media history
item.description: The proposal would expand existing Electronic System for Travel Authorisation requirements to include personal data spanning years.

item.title: Richard Marles attends first AUKUS ministerial meeting |Morning News Bulletin 11 December 2025
item.description: Defence Minister Richard Marles attends AUKUS ministerial meeting with his US and UK counterparts, Iceland becomes the fifth country to boycott Eurovision 2026 after Israel given the go-ahead to compete, Hip surgery deals a blow to Soceroos veteran Mathew Lecki.

item.title: 'Profoundly distressing milestone': Indigenous deaths in custody highest in 45 years
item.description: Grim figures reveal 33 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people died in custody in 2024-25 — the highest number since 1980.

item.title: Evidence reveals humans started fire-making 400,000 years ago after landmark UK find
item.description: The discovery pushes back global fire-making timelines and suggests our ancestors transported materials, such as iron pyrite, to spark flames.

item.title: Evidence reveals humans started fire-making 400,000 years ago after landmark UK find
item.description: The discovery pushes back global fire-making timelines and suggests our ancestors transported materials, such as iron pyrite, to spark flames.

item.title: What have we learned in the 20 years since the Cronulla riots?
item.description: Twenty years ago, thousands descended on the Sydney beachside suburb of Cronulla for what became a violent rally against Middle Eastern immigration. Today, Cronulla locals and some Australians of Middle Eastern descent say attitudes are changing. But others are concerned about new, more organised anti-immigration movements.

item.title: From Calibri to Times New Roman: Why the US state department changed its font again
item.description: The US state department started using Calibri, a modern sans-serif font that is more accessible for people with disabilities, during the Biden administration in January 2023.

item.title: US seizes tanker off Venezuela and 'other things are happening', Trump says
item.description: The seizure marks an escalation in tensions in the region, where a large US military presence has built up in recent weeks.

item.title: New jab for new COVID-19 variant: Australians can now access additional vaccine
item.description: The federal health department says regular COVID-19 vaccinations are "the best way" to maintain protection.

item.title: Australians to be caught up in Trump visa plan | Midday News Bulletin 11 December 2025
item.description: Australians to be caught up in a new Trump plan to screen visitors to the US; At least 22 dead in a Morocco building collapse; England's cricket team attracts attention for their mid Ashes campaign break in Noosa.

item.title: Australian, US and UK Defence Mnisters meet to discuss AUKUS and the 'apex predator of the seas'
item.description: United States Australian and British defence ministers have met at the Pentagon for the first AUKUS ministerial meeting with Secretary of Defence Pete Hegseth. Hegseth welcomed Australian Defence Minister Richard Marles and UK Minister of Defence John Healey.

item.title: Thailand and Cambodia accuse each other of targeting civilians, as Trump urges calm
item.description: Border clashes between the Southeast Asian countries have reignited, months after they signed a US-brokered ceasefire.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 11 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Venezuela calls oil tanker seizure international piracy
item.description: President Donald Trump says US forces have seized the largest oil tanker ever intercepted off Venezuela’s coast, escalating Washington’s maritime campaign against vessels it claims support Nicolás Maduro or drug smuggling operations. Venezuela's government has accused the US of theft and international piracy. It has previously said it believes the United States is trying to depose President Maduro.

item.title: US defends seizure of oil tanker off Venezuela coast | Evening News Bulletin 11 December 2025
item.description: The PM calls on the states to do more to prevent First Nations deaths in custody; The US defends its seizure of an oil tanker off Venezuela; The Australian Olympic Committee unveils a new funding package for athletes.

item.title: DRC & the Thai-Cambodia border wars, Syria a year after Assad & Trump finally gets his peace prize... sort of
item.description: Ceasefires are collapsing from Southeast Asia to eastern DRC, with civilians once again bearing the brunt of diplomatic failure. Plus, one year after the fall of the brutal Assad regime, are Syrians any better off? And FIFA honours President Trump – but is the prize an own goal?

item.title: 'Repugnant' text messages highlighted in NT's appeal of fatal hit-and-run sentence
item.description: The case of a driver who received a 12-month community corrections order for a fatal hit-and-run is back before the courts.

item.title: 'Is this actually helping?' How Trump's tourist disclosure plan would affect Australians
item.description: The US appears to be cracking down on speech criticising the government but experts say Australians may not have much to worry about.

item.title: US cuts rates as Australia's economy loses jobs
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Darren Thompson from Equity Trustees and Diana Mousina from AMP about the impact lower US interest rates and today's local labour force data is having on the sharemarket and what it means for local rates.

item.title: Indigenous deaths in custody reach four decade high
item.description: Australia has recorded the highest number of Indigenous deaths in custody in four decades. Data from the Australian Institute of Criminology finds 33 of the 113 people who died in police or prison custody in the last financial year were First Nations.

item.title: Twenty years on from the Cronulla riots, how have racial tensions in Australia changed?
item.description: The Cronulla riots prompted a national reckoning on racism. How have things changed in the two decades since?
